id: Ownership.rdf version of the ontology was modified to better align with revisions to the situation lattice.
name: Ownership.rdf version of the ontology was modified to better align with revisions to the situation lattice.

id: identifies the actor that holds title to the asset in an ownership situation
name: identifies the actor that holds title to the asset in an ownership situation

id: identifies an asset that an owner owns
name: identifies an asset that an owner owns

id: Ownership.rdf version of the ontology was modified to revise the definition of Asset using the new CombinedDateTime datatype rather than xsd:dateTime to provide increased flexibility.
name: Ownership.rdf version of the ontology was modified to revise the definition of Asset using the new CombinedDateTime datatype rather than xsd:dateTime to provide increased flexibility.

id: identifies the owner of an asset
name: identifies the owner of an asset

id: Ownership.rdf version of this ontology was modified to replace content that is now available in the OMG Commons Ontology Library (Commons) v1.1 (FND-380).
name: Ownership.rdf version of this ontology was modified to replace content that is now available in the OMG Commons Ontology Library (Commons) v1.1 (FND-380).

id: Ownership.rdf version of the ontology was modified to use the Commons Ontology Library (Commons) Annotation Vocabulary rather than the OMG's Specification Metadata vocabulary.
name: Ownership.rdf version of the ontology was modified to use the Commons Ontology Library (Commons) Annotation Vocabulary rather than the OMG's Specification Metadata vocabulary.

id: This ontology defines high-level, ownership-related concepts, including owner, asset and ownership along with relationships between them.
name: This ontology defines high-level, ownership-related concepts, including owner, asset and ownership along with relationships between them.

id: asset that is a physical, measurable resource, i.e., one that takes a physical form
name: asset that is a physical, measurable resource, i.e., one that takes a physical form

id: indicates the asset in an ownership situation
name: indicates the asset in an ownership situation

id: Intangible assets may include intellectual property, patents, copyrights, trademarks, rights-of-way (easements), brands, organizational abilities (know-how), and data.
name: Intangible assets may include intellectual property, patents, copyrights, trademarks, rights-of-way (easements), brands, organizational abilities (know-how), and data.

id: Ownership.rdf version of the ontology was modified to integrate the concept of a situation, situational roles, and corresponding relations with the definition of ownership, and eliminate minimum cardinality of 1 in restrictions.
name: Ownership.rdf version of the ontology was modified to integrate the concept of a situation, situational roles, and corresponding relations with the definition of ownership, and eliminate minimum cardinality of 1 in restrictions.

id:
ontology structure
	(5) to incorporate changes to the specification metadata to support documentation at the family, specification, module, and ontology level, similar to the abbreviations.
name:
ontology structure
	(5) to incorporate changes to the specification metadata to support documentation at the family, specification, module, and ontology level, similar to the abbreviations.

id: Ownership.rdf version of the ontology was modified to reflect the move of hasAquisitionDate from relations to financial dates and eliminate circular definitions.
name: Ownership.rdf version of the ontology was modified to reflect the move of hasAquisitionDate from relations to financial dates and eliminate circular definitions.

id: Ownership.rdf version of the ontology was modified to add definitions for tangible and intangible asset, etc., as needed for refinement of the concept of collateral and other loan-specific concepts.
name: Ownership.rdf version of the ontology was modified to add definitions for tangible and intangible asset, etc., as needed for refinement of the concept of collateral and other loan-specific concepts.

id: Intangible assets include assets that may involve a legal claim to some future benefit, typically a claim to future cash. Intangible assets have become an increasingly larger component of the valuation for all companies, from newer social media companies to even the most established and iconic manufacturers.
name: Intangible assets include assets that may involve a legal claim to some future benefit, typically a claim to future cash. Intangible assets have become an increasingly larger component of the valuation for all companies, from newer social media companies to even the most established and iconic manufacturers.

id: something of monetary value that is owned or provides benefit to some party
name: something of monetary value that is owned or provides benefit to some party

id: indicates the context of ownership in which something is an asset
name: indicates the context of ownership in which something is an asset

id: Ownership.rdf version of the ontology was modified to address hygiene issues with respect to text formatting.
name: Ownership.rdf version of the ontology was modified to address hygiene issues with respect to text formatting.

id: party that is legally recognized as having the right to possess, the privilege to use, and ability to transfer any rights or privileges associated with something, as permitted by law
name: party that is legally recognized as having the right to possess, the privilege to use, and ability to transfer any rights or privileges associated with something, as permitted by law

id: Tangible assets include cash, cash equivalents and accounts receivables (AR), inventory, equipment, buildings and real estate, crops, and investments. Tangible assets such as art, furniture, stamps, gold, wine, toys and books of significant value may be included in an individual or organization's asset portfolio.
name: Tangible assets include cash, cash equivalents and accounts receivables (AR), inventory, equipment, buildings and real estate, crops, and investments. Tangible assets such as art, furniture, stamps, gold, wine, toys and books of significant value may be included in an individual or organization's asset portfolio.

id: Ownership.rdf version of this ontology was modified to use the Commons Ontology Library (Commons) rather than the OMG's Languages, Countries and Codes (LCC), eliminating redundancies in FIBO as appropriate.
name: Ownership.rdf version of this ontology was modified to use the Commons Ontology Library (Commons) rather than the OMG's Languages, Countries and Codes (LCC), eliminating redundancies in FIBO as appropriate.

id: Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) Statement of Financial Accounting Concepts No. 6, Elements of Financial Statements, paragraph 25.
name: Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) Statement of Financial Accounting Concepts No. 6, Elements of Financial Statements, paragraph 25.

id: indicates the context of ownership in which the party plays the role of owner
name: indicates the context of ownership in which the party plays the role of owner

id: An asset is something that provides probable future economic benefit obtained or controlled by some party as a result of past transactions or events. An asset has three essential characteristics: (a) it embodies a probable future benefit that involves a capacity, singly or in combination with other assets, to contribute directly or indirectly to future net cash inflows, (b) a party can obtain the benefit and control others' access to it, and (c) the transaction or other event giving rise to the party's right to or control of the benefit has already occurred.
name: An asset is something that provides probable future economic benefit obtained or controlled by some party as a result of past transactions or events. An asset has three essential characteristics: (a) it embodies a probable future benefit that involves a capacity, singly or in combination with other assets, to contribute directly or indirectly to future net cash inflows, (b) a party can obtain the benefit and control others' access to it, and (c) the transaction or other event giving rise to the party's right to or control of the benefit has already occurred.

id: indicates something that a party holds title to and may possess
name: indicates something that a party holds title to and may possess

id: identifiable, non-monetary asset that lacks physical substance
name: identifiable, non-monetary asset that lacks physical substance
